bibl.title: Ah Jack v. C. D. Hanford. Petition of Intervention
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: United States Circuit Court for the District of Washington

div1.ab: IN THE UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON. NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the matter of the petition of Ah Jack, a Chinaman, for a writ of Habeas Corpus.
div1.p: To the Honorable Cornelius H. Hanford, Judge of said Court:
The United States, having first obtained leave to intervene herein come now and present their petition of intervention, in this cause, and as grounds of intervention say state
That the prayer of the petitioner in this cause ought not to be granted because intervenors say:-

That they deny each and every allegation in the petition filed herein, except, that the said petitioner was apprehended on the 27th day of April, 1894, for being unlawfully in the United States and that on the 30 th day of April, 1894, he was ordered to be deported from the United States to China by C. D. Emery, United States Commissioner.

Intervenors further say that the said petition and prayer thereof should not be granted for the reason that the said Ah Jack is a Chinese laborer, and that he was on the said 27th day of April, 1894, unlawfully in the United States and not entitled to be or remain in the United States.
That the said Ah Jack was on July 14, 1888, arrested and charged with being unlawfullyin the United States; that he was on said day tried upon said charge before C. D. Emery, United States Commission

-er, he, the said C.D. Emery, having then and there competent jurisdiction to hear, try and determine such charge, and was by the consideration and judgment of said commissioner, ordered and ad- -judged to be unlawfully in the United States, and was then and there by said commissioner ordered deported from the United States and returned to the Province of British Columbia, the foreign country from which he came, and that said C. D. Emery then and there pursuant to said judgment issued his proper writ of deporta- tion, directed to the Marshal of the United States for the District of Washington, commanding the said Marshal to forthwith deport the said Ah Jack from the United States to the Province of British Columbia, and that the said United States Marshal did, without delay, execute the said writ of deportation by taking the said Ah Jack and removing him to the Province of British Columbia.

And that thereafter, and while said judgment was in full force, unappealed, from and unreversed, the said Ah Jack, on or and about the first day of August, 1888, returned to the United States unlawfully and was again arrested under and by the name of Ah Jap, and charged before said C. D. Emery with being unlawfully in the United States and on the 4th day of August, 1888, the said Ah Jack Jck under the name of Ah Jap, was tried before said C. D. Emery, United States Commissioner, upon said charge, he, the said C. D. Emery, then and there having competent authority to hear and determine the same, and the said Ah Jack, under and by the name of Ah Jap, was by the said C. D. Emery then and there adjudged to be unlawfully in the United States, and ordered deported to the Province of British Columbia; that said order of deportation was duly executed by the Marshal of the United States for the District of Washington

by deporting the said Ah Jack to the Province of British Columbia; That thereafter, and before the 21st day of August, 1888, and while the said judgment of deportation was in full force, unappeal- ed from and unreversed, the said Ah Jack unalwfully returned to the United States, and was again arrested, and charged before C.D. Emery, United States Commissioner, under and by the name of of Ah % Gap, with being unlawfully in the United States, and said charge was duly tried before the said C. D. Emery, United States Commissioner as aforesaid, he, the said C.D. Emery, having com- petent authority to hear and determine the said charge, and on the 21st day of August, 1888, said commissioner upon full con- -sideration adjudged the said Ah Jack, under and by the name of Ah Gap, to be unlawfully in the United States and ordered him to be deported to the Province of British Columbia; that the said order of deportation was duly executed by the Marshal of the United States for the District of Washington by conveying the body of the said Ah Jack to the Province of British Columbia: That there- after, at some time before the 16th day of August, 1890, the said Ah Jack unlawfully returned to the United States, and was arrested, while the above mentioned judgments were all in full force, unappealed, from and unreversed, and charged before said C. D. Emery, said United States Commissioner, with being a Chinese laborore unlawfully in the United States, he, the said C. D. Emery, having then and there competent authority to hear and de -termine said charge, and the said Ah Jack, under and by the name of Ah Jack, alias Ah Jap, was on the 16th day of August, 1890, tried before the said C. D. Emery, and the said C. D. Emery, after hearing all the evidence, and upon full consideration adjudged the said Ah Jack to be then and there unlawfully in the United States,

and ordered that he should be deported to the Province of British Columbia, that the United States Marshal for the District of Wash- -ington duly executed said order by conveying the said Ah Jack to the Province of British Columbia; That thereafter the said Ah Jack, while the aforesaid judgment of deportation was in full force, unappealed from, and unreversed, unlawfully returned to the United States, and was thereafter arrested, taken before the said C. D. Emery, and then and there charged with being unlawfully in the United States, the said C. D. Emery having competent author- -ity as aforesaid, adjudged the said Ah Jack to be then and there unlawfully in the United States, and on May 3, 1894, ordered the said Ah Jack to be deported to the Empire of China, and that the said order and judgment of the said C. D. Emery is still in full force, unappealed from, and unreversed.
WHEREFORE the said intervenors pray that the said peiition be dismissed, and that they recover their costs and disbursements herein expended.
In the United States Circuit Court FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON
Ah Jack Petitioner Exha vs for writ of Habeas Corpus

ab.del: FILED 6/29 1894 IN THE U.S.DISTRICT COURT R M Hopkins Clerk By Deputy

div1.ab: Attorney for Intervenors 5 and 6 Colman Block Seattle Wash
FILED June 29 - 1894 -IN THE- U.S. CIRCUIT COURT. A. REEVES AYRES CLERK.
